sentence.content: THE CONDITION known in cattle as &apost;mad cow disease&apost;, spongiform encephalopathies, has been found in Britain&apost;s sparsely-scattered antelope population, the government has admitted.

sentence.content: Three elands, three greater kudu and an arabian oryx have been diagnosed with the disease over the past three years.

sentence.content: The statistics - released in response to a written question from Mr Ron Davies, a Labour agriculture spokesman - show a disconcertingly rapid increase in the number of sheep found to have the disease.

sentence.content: A total of 894 cases of sheep encephalopathies or &apost;scrapie&apost; were diagnosed in 1991, versus just 348 a year-earlier.

sentence.content: However, the government states in a footnote to the table that the reporting of scrapie in sheep has been encouraged since 1991 &apost;to obtain material for spongiform encephalopathy research&apost;.

sentence.content: Mr David Maclean, junior agriculture minister, stressed that naturally occurring spongiform encephalopathies in species other than cattle were not notifiable diseases.
